item.title: Marvel Rivals' Roster Strikes a Good Balance That Needs to be Carefully Maintained
item.description:
Marvel Rivals has no shortage of great qualities, from its vibrant comic-inspired art direction, to its clean menu UI and general presentation, to its great performances from actors who have become synonymous with the roles. But that would all be for nothing if Marvel Rivals ' gameplay wasn't fun.

Thankfully, Marvel Rivals is a really engaging hero shooter that strikes a really great balance of being accessible enough to welcome newcomers to the genre, while still offering enough complexity in its mechanics to reward veterans of the genre. Marvel Rivals also strikes a pretty good balance with its roster, in several key ways. But developer NetEase can't rest on its laurels.

Marvel Rivals' Roster Needs To Be Carefully Maintained

Marvel Rivals' Roster Is Home to a Variety of Heroes

One of Marvel Rivals ' biggest strengths is the variety of its roster. Marvel Rivals has shipped with an impressive total of 33 characters, each one coming with a very distinct moveset. While the roster is home to household names like Hulk, Captain America, Spider-Man, Iron Man, and Black Panther, it also has its fair share of lesser-known heroes. Interestingly, it's several of these lesser-known heroes who have become the breakout stars of Marvel Rivals , with Iron Fist becoming a notorious back-line menace, and Jeff the Land Shark being an adorable little team-eating fiend.

Marvel Rivals' Roster Strikes a Solid Balance Between Roles

Another solid balance that Marvel Rivals ' roster strikes is between its roles. While the number of heroes in each of Marvel Rivals ' classes are far from equal, it still feels as though there's a solid balance overall while playing. With Marvel Rivals ' 6v6 team structure, at least half of the team is expected to choose to be a Duelist (Damage), and there are 18 different heroes to choose from, giving players a ton of playstyle variety and giving teams a plethora of different strategies they can work with.

Though there are far fewer Vanguards (Tanks) and Strategist (Supports) in Marvel Rivals , there's still plenty of variation for players to experiment with. The complexity of some of Marvel Rivals ' Vanguards and Strategists also requires a bit more skill to master, meaning that it can often be more rewarding to play as a tank or support despite the fewer heroes available to players.

Marvel Rivals' Roster Could Lose Its Balance Quite Easily

But while Marvel Rivals ' roster is striking a solid balance right now, that could be thrown out of whack pretty easily if developer NetEase isn't careful. There are currently 18 Duelists in Marvel Rivals , and just 8 Vanguards, and 7 Strategists. That's obviously a sizable gap, and though it's solid for a launch-day roster ( Overwatch 1 had just four Support heroes at launch), it won't be long before fans start to demand more heroes to fill that void.

Though it's surely tempting to put more Duelists in Marvel Rivals as their abilities only need to focus on dishing out damage, NetEase needs to make sure it adds new Vanguard and Strategist heroes first. Maintaining this careful balance is pivotal to the success of a hero shooter.

item.title: Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered Releases New Update for December 2024
item.description:
Summary

  • Patch 1.08 for Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered adds a transmog feature and bug fixes.
  • The patch includes fixed background flickering along with improved audio mix, mount acceleration, and motion aiming.
  • Despite slow sales, the remastered game offers an engrossing open-world experience for fans.

Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered has recently unveiled the official patch notes for its Patch 1.08. The new Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered update is already available for PS5, addresses several issues that the title previously had, and adds a new feature to the open-world game.

Developed by Guerrilla Games and Nixxes Software, Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered was released earlier this year for PS5 and PC. The game is a remaster of the popular 2017 title with enhanced graphics, and it takes advantage of some PS5 features such as haptic feedback. Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered received positive reviews from critics, and it currently holds an average score of 85 on OpenCritic.

Now, Guerrilla Games and Nixxes Software revealed Patch 1.08 for Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered , which adds a transmog functionality to the game, allowing gamers to pick how Aloy’s armor will look despite the actual armor they’re wearing. To access this function, gamers should open their Inventory, go to Outfits, and select Apply Look on the desired costume. The rest of the patch mostly focused on fixing several bugs, such as flickering backgrounds during cutscenes, issues when using Auto Pickup for items, or mount acceleration not working as intended. Other fixes include improvements to the game’s audio, fixing various minor visual issues, and gameplay elements such as motion aiming not working properly while riding a mount.

The new patch comes on the heels of Update 1.07 for Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered , which was released for PS5 late in November. This previous update introduced elements such as Auto Pickup to the Pickups setting and a Color Blind Mode, and addressed some other bugs and minor issues.

Despite the positive reviews and continued support from the developers, Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered is not selling very well on the PS5. According to a recent report from TrueTrophies, the game had a small impact on PS5 players when compared to The Last of Us Part 2 Remastered , having 92% fewer players than the other Sony remaster.

Despite some issues attracting an audience, Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered remains one of the best PlayStation exclusives. The original 2017 game was already a pretty engrossing open-world adventure, and the remaster makes the experience more in line with the recent Horizon Forbidden West , making the title an excellent pick for fans who have not played it yet. Gamers who are looking for more, however, should keep an eye out for the next game in the Horizon franchise, which could be released in 2025, according to some rumors.

Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered PS5 - Patch 1.08 Official Patch Notes

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Patch 1.08 for Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered is available now on PlayStation 5. This update adds transmog functionality, allowing you to apply a different look to Aloy's armor. To do so, open the Inventory, go to Outfits, and select Apply Look on the outfit that you want to be visible while playing the game.

We've also addressed various bugs based on player feedback. Check out the patch notes below for all the details. Thanks to everyone for playing Horizon Zero Dawn Remastered and for providing feedback to help us further improve the game!

  • Added outfit transmog functionality.
  • Fixed flickering visible in the background during cutscenes and conversations in some scenarios.
  • Fixed a bug that could cause Concentration to activate unexpectedly.
  • Improvements to audio mix to reduce excessive reverb in specific areas.
  • Audio mix adjustments to conversation dialogue panning.
  • Various audio loudness and balance improvements.
  • Mount acceleration now works as intended, incrementally increasing speed when the acceleration button is pressed.
  • Motion aiming now works as intended when riding a mount.
  • Fixed a bug that could cause a hang on a black screen when starting a New Game+ from imported PS4 save data.
  • Custom button bindings for Mount actions now conflict as intended when binding multiple actions to the same key or button.
  • Fixed a bug that prevented music from playing during a scene in the ‘Deep Secrets of Earth’ quest.
  • Fixed a bug where Nil would disappear after talking to him during Cause for Concern.
  • Various bug fixes related to Auto Pickup.
  • Fixes for various bugs and minor visual issues.

item.title: Tales of the Shire Can't Ignore Bywater's Original Lore Significance
item.description:
Summary

  • Tales of the Shire should subtly foreshadow the Battle of Bywater to tie in with The Lord of the Rings lore.
  • The game presents a chance to hint at an impending war due to the short timeline between The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings.
  • Possibility for Tales of the Shire to incorporate Saruman's influence, ominous signs, and Gandalf's warnings for richer storytelling.

With Tales of the Shire confirmed to take place between The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings , there's massive potential for this cozy little farm life sim to subtly foreshadow the War of the Ring and therefore one of Bywater's most historic events: the Battle of Bywater. In The Lord of the Rings , the Battle of Bywater is the last battle fought in the War of the Ring, in the year 3019, making it not just an important event for Bywater but for all of Middle-earth. With Tales of the Shire doing everything it can to be as true to its source material as possible, there is little reason why it wouldn't find some way to reference the iconic war and the final battle that ended it.

There's no indication of a specific year that Tales of the Shire is set in, but since there are only 77 years between The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings , there is plenty of opportunity for Tales of the Shire to at least hint at an impending war coming. While talk of a war as oppressive as the War of the Ring and the Battle of Bywater that followed it might seem out of place in a farm life sim like Tales of the Shire , it might actually be the perfect way for the game to offset its bright, joyous tones every once in a while and expand its worldbuilding in the process.

Tales of the Shire Should at Least Foreshadow the Battle of Bywater

In The Lord of the Rings , once the One Ring is destroyed and Sauron is defeated, Frodo, Sam, Merry, and Pippin return home to the Shire, expecting to find everything is still the way they left it. Instead, they discover that Saruman's henchmen have taken over the Shire and industrialized it for the fallen wizard's purposes. The Hobbits then organize a resistance and overwhelm the ruffians in a coordinated ambush near the village of Bywater, freeing the Shire and its inhabitants from Saruman's control.

There's no indication of a specific year that Tales of the Shire is set in, but since there are only 77 years between The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings , there is plenty of opportunity for Tales of the Shire to at least hint at an impending war coming.

As Saruman is ultimately the driving force of the threat against Bywater, perhaps Tales of the Shire could hint at the wizard's growing influence and the potential for a hostile takeover of the Shire. Saruman's industrialization of the Shire likely would have been in its earliest stages just before the start of the War of the Ring, so it's possible (depending on how close it is set to the war) for Tales of the Shire to somehow weave Saruman's plot into its narrative. Perhaps Hobbits around Bywater might gossip about trouble in Bree, mysterious movements along the Greenway, or strange activity around Isengard.

As players are exploring Bywater and its outskirts in Tales of the Shire , perhaps they might come across peculiar tools or unfamiliar items, hinting at Saruman's industrial ambitions. It might make sense for certain parts of the Shire to begin showing signs of decay as well, if not just as a symbolic way of foreshadowing the war to come. Furthermore, since it seems Gandalf will make an appearance in Tales of the Shire , according to what is shown in its various trailers, the wizard could even drop hints about potential dangers throughout the wider Middle-earth and caution the villagers of Bywater to stay safe.

As an Easter egg for fans of Lord of the Rings lore, characters could even vaguely reference someone nicknamed "Sharkey," Saruman's alias during his gradual takeover of the Shire.

In the end, Tales of the Shire has a unique opportunity to bridge the gap between its cozy, casual farm life sim persona and the deeper lore and narrative of The Lord of the Rings by foreshadowing the impending war and its concluding Battle of Bywater. By incorporating subtle hints of Saruman's growing influence, whispers of unrest in Middle-earth, and symbolic representations of the looming threat, Tales of the Shire can innovate on the cozy farm life sim tones it is expected to maintain to make its story and world much more than it seems.

item.title: Star Wars Outlaws Releases Update 1.5
item.description:
Summary

  • Star Wars Outlaws released update 1.5.0, fixing bugs related to NPCs, Sabaac mini-game, quests, and performance.
  • Massive Entertainment removed forced stealth from Star Wars Outlaws in update 1.4.0, allowing players to play stealth or loud.
  • Star Wars Outlaws earned three Game Awards nominations, including Best Action/Adventure Game and Innovation in Accessibility.

Star Wars Outlaws has released title update 1.5.0, which fixes bugs related to NPCs, the Sabaac mini-game, quests, performance, and more. Star Wars Outlaws is one of the more divisive games of 2024, with some praising it for its open world design and scoundrel fantasy, while others felt alienated by its stealth-focused gameplay. Despite all this, Star Wars Outlaws earned an impressive three nominations at the 2024 Game Awards for Humberly Gonzalez's performance as Key Vess, Best Action/Adventure Game, and Innovation in Accessiblity.

One of the biggest points of contention when Star Wars Outlaws first launched was its large focus on stealth gameplay. Many players were turned off by the game's forced stealth areas with automatic fail states when caught by guards or going loud. In the previous update, 1.4.0, developer Massive Entertainment removed Star Wars Outlaws ' forced stealth, allowing for players to be able to tackle these areas with blaster in hand. Of course, stealth has remained a viable option for players who prefer to remain quiet, they just won't get an automatic failure screen when caught.

Now, Massive Entertainment has gone ahead and rolled out Star Wars Outlaws ' latest title update, 1.5.0, which addresses large swaths of the game. Headlining the update are some fixes to NPCs, such as issues with them entering and exiting cover, getting trapped in an Imperial base on Toshara, and basic clipping issues with their clothing. Performance is a top focus of update 1.5.0 as well, as Massive has addressed a frame drop issue related to RTDXI and improved frame generation for players who use DLSS.

Star Wars Outlaws ' popular Poker-like card game Sabaac has also received a healthy dose of fixes in the new update as well. An issue making tables unplayable after leaving with certain Shift Tokens active has been resolved, as well as the suspicion mechanic not working properly when players cheat with Kay Vess' companion Nix during a game. The update addresses main and side quest bugs across all the game's explorable planets, as well as a large number of issues having to do with Star Wars Outlaws ' Wild Card story DLC. Despite its divisive launch, it's good to see Massive Entertainment actively patching the game up with these massive title updates.

With Star Wars Outlaws' first DLC out the door, Ubisoft still has one more planned to release in the Spring of 2025, named A Pirate's Fortune.

Star Wars Outlaws Title Update 1.5.0 Patch Notes

General Gameplay

  • Balanced damage done to ionized enemies
  • Fixed an issue with NPC collision area in syndicate districts that prevented shooting in some situations
  • Smoothed NPC transitions for going in/out cover
  • Fixed an issue where capital ships would not spawn in space
  • Improved enemy AI when detecting grenades and when Kay is hidden in smoke
  • Fixed an issue where enemies would take cover behind hollow fences
  • Fixed an issue where fast travelling on Akiva to the Abandoned Hideout could cause an infinite loading screen
  • Fixed an issue where the Wanted status would not decrease in certain areas
  • Fixed an issue where some NPCs would get stuck in combat areas in an Imperial compound on Toshara
  • Fixed an issue where VFX would impact the entire screen when shooting outdoors from an indoors location

Performance

  • Fixed an issue that caused performance drops when aiming the camera straight down with RTDXI enabled

Graphics

  • Fixed an issue with flickering lights at the bottom of the screen on consoles

UI, HUD and Settings

  • Updated options for Frame Generation and DLSS
  • Improved detection when 'in-combat' state
  • Fixed an issue where item descriptions would not show in the loadout menu
  • Fixed an issue where intention icons no longer appeared above NPCs

Audio

  • Fixed combat music not playing in syndicate territories in cities
  • Lowered Nix's footsteps volume
  • Fixed missing contract VO's
  • Improved music playback in The High Roller quest
  • Improved Flyer creature foley playback
  • Improved VO loudness issues on localized versions of the game

Cinematics

  • Improved quality of 'The Deal' cinematic in Wild Card
  • Fixed an issue where characters could get stuck in a T-pose during the sabacc tournament in Wild Card

Camera

  • Fixed an issue where Kay's head would face a different direction than the camera

Worlds, Fauna and Flora

  • Improved the takeoff animation of the aglis flyer on Toshara
  • Added additional flee animation and audio to scurriers on Tatooine
  • Fixed an issue with terrain blending on Tatooine

Photo Mode

  • Enabled option to toggle cinematic lens effect
  • Fixed an issue where Nix could be seen clipping through Kay's chair if photo mode is activated when planting a card during sabacc in Wild Card

Accessibility

  • Fixed an issue where in-game objects would not change color when switching between colorblind presets
  • Fixed an issue where simple numerals in sabacc would not show correctly
  • Fixed an issue where swapping a button for 'On Foot' would also change it for the Speeder and Trailblazer
  • Fixed an issue where you could get stuck in the Custom Control screen when using a mouse and keyboard
  • Fixed an issue where the gadgets wheel could not be opened after switching the input to toggle
  • Fixes for various high contrast mode bugs and inconsistencies
  • Narration on the map screen now reads distance to points of interest

Sabacc:

  • Fixed an issue when leaving a sabacc game if an enemy is playing the 'Embargo' or 'Direct Transaction' could prevent continued play at the table
  • Fixed an issue where Kay's left hand would suddenly disappear whilst 'auto-success' was enabled when using the magnetic dice
  • Fixed an issue where suspicion states were not registering correctly when caught cheating
  • Fixed an issue where SFX would play/trigger at incorrect moments

Miscellaneous

  • Fixed an issue where some NPC clothing was clipping
  • Fixed an issue with random floating objects
  • Fixed an issue where defeating enemies using the 'Blast' or 'Pulse' Power module would not count towards the Power Surge Ubisoft Connect Time-Limited Challenge

PS5 Pro

  • In addition to the 'Quality (60FPS)' mode, the three base PS5 options of 'Quality', 'Performance' and 'Balanced' are now selectable graphics options
  • An 'Upscaler Type' toggle has been added allowing you to use either PSSR or FSR

MAIN & SIDE QUESTS (beware of spoilers)

Canto Bight

  • Beginnings
    • Fixed an issue where Kay would be unable to speak to vendors or Preeban after winning a fixed Fathier race

Toshara

  • Codebreaker
    • Fixed an issue where a player could get stuck behind an energy barrier after reloading a save

  • Tosharan Treasure Intel
    • Fixed an issue where the intel chain does not start after reading the IWM datapad

  • The Wreck
    • Fixed an issue where Kay could get stuck navigating a narrow passage

  • Contracts
    • Fixed an issue where a slicing terminal will already show as unlocked if completing a contract for a second time

Tatooine

  • The Hotfixer
    • Fixed an issue where Kay could get stuck by using the speeder boost to jump into the Sarlacc pit

Akiva

  • Viper
    • Fixed an issue where the viper droid could not be damaged once it reached half health

  • Contracts
    • Fixed an issue where a 'Spy on Pyke District' would fail on completion

  • The Veteran
    • Fixed an issue where players were able to access the quest area prematurely

  • The High Roller
    • Fixed an issue where Kay was not able to talk to Lando's associates after the shootout

Kijimi

  • Passenger
    • Fixed an issue where the quest fails when the pirate ship hyperjumps and the mission cannot be complete after a reload

  • The High Roller
  • Fixed an issue where Kay is not able to interact with Avrar to get Lando's token

Wild Card - Story Pack

  • Wild Card
    • Fixed an issue where the mission would not complete if the player is at the maximum Wanted Level
    • Fixed an issue where collecting the intel on the shuttle would not register and progress the quest
    • Fixed an issue where the quest marker does not appear above the shuttle when pressing up on the D-pad

  • The Game
    • Fixed an issue where the mission wasn't automatically tracked in the journal once completing the prior quest
    • Fixed an issue where a platform was incorrectly placed when escaping from the Morenia
    • Fixed an issue where a player could get stuck in a dying loop sequence at the end of the quest

  • Double Down
    • Fixed an issue where the quest item could disappear if not picked up at the Western Camp before defeating enemies at the Southern Camp

  • All In
    • Fixed an issue where actions would not be registered when resuming the game from a pause during a cutscene

item.title: Full Yu-Gi-Oh: Early Days Collection Game List Revealed
item.description:
Summary

  • Yu-Gi-Oh! Early Days Collection will feature 14 classic games released for the Game Boy, Game Boy Color, and Game Boy Advance between 1998 and 2004.
  • The collection will also feature five titles never released outside of Japan.
  • Fans can get their hands on Yu-Gi-Oh! Early Days Collection for Nintendo Switch or PC on February 27, 2025.

Ahead of the title's February 2025 release, Konami has revealed the full list of games players will find in Yu-Gi-Oh! Early Days Collection . Featuring a number of classic titles, including several never released in the West, Yu-Gi-Oh! Early Days Collection will include a total of 14 games when it launches next year.

In February 2024, Konami announced the Yu-Gi-Oh! Early Days Collection as part of the planned festivities to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the Yu-Gi-Oh franchise. All games in the upcoming compilation title were initially released between 1998 and 2004 for the Game Boy, Game Boy Color, or Game Boy Advance, with one title hitting shelves before the physical card game was even released in Japan. Over the past year, more and more titles have been confirmed for the collection, with the complete list now being confirmed by Konami ahead of the game's February 2025 launch.

The Japanese Nintendo eShop page for Yu-Gi-Oh! Early Days Collection has been posted by Konami, finally revealing the entire list of titles fans can expect to find in the upcoming game. Releasing for PC and Nintendo Switch, the collection will be around 4.5 GB, with the English physical Switch version including one of two highly sought-after Quarter Century Secret Rare "Harpie's Feather Duster" cards. Several quality-of-life features will also be included, from a save/load feature to online battle support in Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters 4: Battle of Great Duelist , with additional titles set to add online battle support at a later date. Players can also customize button layouts and other settings for each title.

Yu-Gi-Oh! Early Days Collection Full Game List

  • Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters (1998 / Game Boy)
  • Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters II: Dark Duel Stories (1999 / Game Boy, Game Boy Color)
  • Yu-Gi-Oh! Monster Capsule (2000 / Game Boy Color)
  • Yu-Gi-Oh! Dark Duel Stories (2000 Japan, 2002 United States, 2003 Europe / Game Boy Color)
  • Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters 4: Battle of Great Duelist (2000 / Game Boy Color / Includes Online Battles Support)
  • Yu-Gi-Oh! Dungeon Dice Monsters (2001 Japan, 2003 United States, 2003 Europe / Game Boy Advance)
  • Yu-Gi-Oh! The Eternal Duelist Soul (2001 Japan, 2002 United States, 2003 Europe / Game Boy Advance)
  • Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters 6, Expert 2 (2001 / Game Boy Advance)
  • Yu-Gi-Oh! The Sacred Cards (2002 Japan, 2003 United States, 2004 Europe / Game Boy Advance)
  • Yu-Gi-Oh! Reshef of Destruction (2003 Japan, 2004 United States and Europe / Game Boy Advance)
  • Yu-Gi-Oh! Worldwide Edition: Stairway to the Destined Duel (2003 / Game Boy Advance)
  • Yu-Gi-Oh! World Championship Tournament 2004 (2004 / Game Boy Advance)
  • Yu-Gi-Oh! Destiny Board Traveler (2004 Japan and United States, 2005 Europe / Game Boy Advance)
  • Yu-Gi-Oh! 7 Trials to Glory: World Championship Tournament 2005 (2004 Japan, 2005 United States and Europe / Game Boy Advance)

While certain games in the collection, such as Reshef of Destruction , aren't recalled too fondly by fans of the franchise, The Eternal Duelist Soul remains a wildly popular Yu-Gi-Oh game to this day, referred to by many as one of the best titles in the series. Five of the listed games have never been ported outside of Japan, including the aforementioned Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters 4: Battle of Great Duelists , which was released in December 2000 in three versions: Yugi Deck, Kaiba Deck, and Jonouchi Deck. While many fans are eager to play these Japan-exclusive titles for the first time, others are hoping to see Konami release a PlayStation collection in the future, as titles like Forbidden Memories for the PlayStation and The Duelists of the Roses for the PlayStation 2 remain beloved to this day.

Konami has celebrated the 25th anniversary of the franchise in other ways as well, with exclusive Yu-Gi-Oh trading card game releases and the free-to-play title Yu-Gi-Oh Master Duel offering players free login bonuses and exclusive cards in late 2023. Yu-Gi-Oh! Early Days Collection will be released worldwide for Switch and PC on February 27, 2025.
